stem: The nurse finds an unresponsive client in bed. Place the Basic Life Support (BLS) steps in the correct order according to contemporary guidelines.

options.text: Verify the scene is safe and check for responsiveness.
Check for a pulse and breathing simultaneously for no more than 10 seconds.
Use an Automated External Defibrillator (AED) as soon as it arrives.
Call for help/Activate the emergency response system.

rationale.correct: Current BLS follows the 'C-A-B' sequence (Compressions, Airway, Breathing). (1) Verify need. (2) Get resources. (3) Confirm arrest. (4) Circulation is priority #1. (5) Airway/Breathing second. (6) Defibrillation is the only cure for VF/VT.
rationale.incorrect: The old 'A-B-C' sequence is now 'C-A-B' because delay in compressions significantly reduces survival rates.
clinicalPearls: Allow for full chest recoil between compressions to allow the heart to refill with blood.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'CAB'â€”Compacts first! Do not stop to give breaths before you have started compressions unless it's a pediatric submersion case (rare in general exams).

reviewUnits.heading: Basic Life Support (BLS) Standards
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must maintain current BLS certification. Focus is on high-quality CPR: Depth (2-2.4 inches), Rate (100-120), and minimizing interruptions.
